title: Jo De Baerdemaeker
content:
Jo De Baerdemaeker, born September 8 1974 in Brussels, Belgium, is considered one of the two active typedesigners of Belgium. Frederik Berlaen is the other one.

He is an experienced designer who has a passion for type and typography. Recently graduated at the University of Reading, Jo De Baerdemaeker designed and developed **_Lungta_** , a Tibetan-Roman typeface, and is eager to continue to work as a typeface designer, teacher and consultant.  
He understands the complete creative process from concept to final output and keeps himself up-to-date regarding recent technological developments.

De Baerdemaeker is also ATypI Country Delegate for Belgium.

Education

- **Since October 2005** Jo De Baerdemaeker is undertaking a PhD entitled _Tibetan Typeforms: from their inception in 1738 up to the present day_ [at the Department of Typography and Graphic Communication, University of Reading](http://web.archive.org/web/20141223185925/http:/www.rdg.ac.uk/AcaDepts/lt/), UK.
- **2003-2004** Master of Arts in Typeface Design, [Department of Typography and Graphic Communication, University of Reading](http://web.archive.org/web/20141223185925/http:/www.rdg.ac.uk/AcaDepts/lt/), UK. Graduated with distinction.
- **2001-2003** Postgraduate Aggregate Typography [Plantin-Moretus](http://web.archive.org/web/20141223185925/http:/typophile.com/wiki/Plantin%20Moretus%20Museum) Society, Antwerp, Belgium. Graduated with distinction.
- **1995-1999** Master of Arts Graphic Design and Communication at [Hogeschool Sint Lukas, Brussels](http://web.archive.org/web/20141223185925/http:/www.sintlukas.be/). Graduated with distinction. Awarded as Laureate of 1999. Exhibition at Art Gallery Hogeschool Sint Lukas, Brussels, Belgium (1999).

Writings

- _Tibetan typography, a survey of evolutionary typestyles_,  
dissertation at [University of Reading](http://web.archive.org/web/20141223185925/http:/www.rdg.ac.uk/AcaDepts/lt/), September 2004
- _Jacques-Francois Rosart sculpsit_, essay at [University of Reading](http://web.archive.org/web/20141223185925/http:/www.rdg.ac.uk/AcaDepts/lt/), May 2004
- _Defining a Tibetan character set_, essay at [University of Reading](http://web.archive.org/web/20141223185925/http:/www.rdg.ac.uk/AcaDepts/lt/), January 2004
